{{cpp/named req/title|DefaultConstructible}}
{{cpp/named req/navbar}}

Specifies that an instance of the type can be default constructed.

===Requirements===
The type {{tt|T}} satisfies {{named req/core|DefaultConstructible}} if all following statements and expressions are valid and have their specified effects:

{|table class="wikitable"
|-
!{{nbsp}}Expression/Statement{{nbsp}}
!Postcondition
|-
|{{c|T u;}}
|The object {{c|u}} is [[cpp/language/default initialization|default-initialized]].
|-
|{{c|T u{};}}
|The object {{c|u}} is [[cpp/language/value initialization|value-initialized]] or [[cpp/language/aggregate initialization|aggregate-initialized]].
|-
|{{c|T()}}
{{c|T{}&lt;!----&gt;}}
|A temporary object of type {{tt|T}} is [[cpp/language/value initialization|value-initialized]] or [[cpp/language/aggregate initialization|aggregate-initialized]].
|}

===Notes===
For objects of non-aggregate class type, a public {{lt|cpp/language/default constructor|default constructor}} must be defined (either user-defined or implicitly defined) to satisfy {{named req/core|DefaultConstructible}}.

Non-const objects of [[cpp/language/type|non-class object type]] are always {{named req/core|DefaultConstructible}}.

Const non-class types are not {{named req/core|DefaultConstructible}}.

Const aggregate types are not {{named req/core|DefaultConstructible}} if any of their members is an object of non-class type.

Non-object types (function types, reference types, and the (possibly cv-qualified) type {{c/core|void}}) as well as the const non-object types are never {{named req/core|DefaultConstructible}}.
